story.title: üìñ The Real Story Behind the Game
story.p1: Julien is a real person. In July 2022, he bought a struggling bulk food store in Woluwe-Saint-Pierre, Brussels, from Genevi√®ve‚Äîthe previous owner who was ready to retire. He started with almost nothing: no savings, just a dream of transforming this dying √©picerie into something special.
story.p2: The shop came with ‚Ç¨38,000 of "stock" on paper‚Äîquinoa from 2019, organic lentils that nobody wanted, cacao powder gathering dust. The √©picerie s√®che (dry goods) market was dying, down 23% industry-wide. But Julien saw what others didn't: the neighborhood needed a fromagerie.
story.p3: September 2023 brought Poncho‚Äîan Australian Shepherd with endless energy who became the shop's mascot. Customers came just to see him. Kids would visit daily. He forced Julien to take walks, which turned out to be the best stress relief.
story.p4: In November 2023, Madame Malfait (the landlord) called with news: she was selling the building. ‚Ç¨380,000 total, ‚Ç¨80,000 down payment needed by July 2024. Eight months to save what seemed impossible. The countdown began.
story.p5: July 2024: Against all odds, Julien bought the building. His hand trembled signing the papers. No more landlord. No more vulnerability. The shop was truly his.
story.p6: September 2024: Lucas joined the team‚Äîyoung, chaotic, passionate about food. He came from the shop next door and brought energy (sometimes too much). Then in early 2025, Lucas's friend Henry arrived‚Äîcalm, reliable, the perfect balance. Finally, Julien could delegate.
story.p7: The burnout was real. The Sunday question was real. The Swiss raclette trip, the December rushes, the AFSCA inspections‚Äîall real. This game is Julien's actual journey, compressed into 43 months.
story.p8: Every event in this game is based on something that actually happened.

cash_crisis.title: No More Grace
cash_crisis.dynamicDescription: You've used all 3 supplier grace periods. Now you're ‚Ç¨{{amount}} short and they won't wait anymore. You need to find money NOW or the shop closes.

choices.outcome: The bank approved your loan. The interest rate hurts‚Äî6% per month. But the suppliers get paid.

choices.hint: They'll help, but it costs something else

sunday_opening.title: The Sunday Question
sunday_opening.description: Day one. The previous owner was closed Sundays. But you see other shops open. That's a great opportunity. More revenue, more visibility. But also: no days off. Only Mondays... This is your first big decision.

choices.hint: Could be up to 20% more revenue - substantial extra
choices.outcome: Sundays are busy. Not the busiest, but good. You now work 6 days a week. Only Mondays off.
You kept Sundays sacred. Your body thanks you. Your family sees you at least one day.

stock_reality.title: The Inventory
stock_reality.description: Two weeks in, you finally finish counting everything. The ‚Ç¨38,000 in stock on paper... doesn't match reality. Bulk quinoa from 2019. Organic lentils that smell strange. Cacao en poudre nobody wants. The √©picerie s√®che is dying‚Äîsales down 23% industry-wide. Realistically, maybe ‚Ç¨10,000 is sellable. The rest is just... there.

choices.text: Progressive liquidation - flea markets, deep discounts
choices.hint: It's going to be a lot of work...
choices.outcome: You spent weekends at flea markets. Bulk bins at -70%. The organic rice finally moved. Customers noticed you care. Space cleared for products people actually want‚Äîlike cheese.

choices.text: Find a "guy" to take the bulk stuff
choices.hint: Someone who buys dead stock, no questions asked
choices.outcome: A contact of a contact showed up with a van. Handed you ‚Ç¨1,500 for stuff worth ‚Ç¨10,000 wholesale. You didn't ask questions. Problem solved, but no lessons learned.

choices.text: Keep trying to sell it normally
choices.hint: Maybe customers will come around eventually?
choices.outcome: You kept the bulk bins. They gathered dust. Products expired. The smell drove customers away. Every month, you threw away more stock and more money.

shop_name.title: What's In a Name?
shop_name.description: The shop came with a generic name. But customers have started calling it different things. Some regulars say "Chez Julien" after you. Your friend Alix suggests "Alix Corner" would sound trendier. Maybe it's time to make it yours.

choices.text: "Chez Julien" - embrace what customers already call it
choices.outcome: You painted "Chez Julien" on the window. Regulars smiled‚Äî"Finally! That's what we've been calling it anyway." It felt right.

choices.hint: Fresh branding, might attract new crowd
choices.outcome: The new sign looks professional. Some regulars are confused. "Who's Alix?" New customers seem to like it though.

choices.hint: No need to change what works
choices.outcome: You kept things as they were. Names matter less than what you do anyway.

insurance_decision.title: The Insurance Question
insurance_decision.description: Your accountant sends you the annual insurance renewal. "Shop insurance covers fire, theft... but comprehensive coverage including flood and water damage is ‚Ç¨1,800/year extra. Most shop owners skip it‚Äîit's expensive and floods are rare in this area." She shrugs. "Your call."

choices.outcome: You signed up for full coverage. ‚Ç¨150/month, automatically deducted. Peace of mind has a price.

choices.hint: Save money, hope for the best
choices.outcome: You went with the basic plan. What are the chances of a flood anyway? The ‚Ç¨1,800 stays in your account.

first_cheese.title: A Customer's Suggestion
first_cheese.description: A regular customer, Madame Dubois, sighs looking at your bulk bins. "What this neighborhood really needs is good cheese. There's nowhere to buy proper fromage around here." She's not the first to mention it. You remember the sales analysis: cheese has x2 margins, strong demand, low competition locally.

choices.text: Start with ONE cheese - Tomme Larzac
choices.outcome: You called Lalero, ordered one wheel of Tomme Larzac. Creamy, nutty, crowd-pleaser. It sold out in 3 days. Customers asked: "When will you have more?"

choices.text: Go big - state of the art counter
choices.outcome: You bought a ‚Ç¨50,000 professional cheese counter. Stunning. The monthly payments are brutal, but this is a statement: you're serious about cheese.

choices.hint: This is what you bought into
choices.outcome: You doubled down on organic bulk. The neighborhood wanted cheese. They went elsewhere for it.

first_christmas.title: Your First Christmas Season
first_christmas.description: December arrives. Your first December as a shop owner. Other fromageries seem to know exactly what to do‚Äîgift baskets, special displays, extended hours. You... don't. The cheese is there. The customers trickle in. But you feel like you're improvising while everyone else has a plan.

choices.text: Keep it simple - focus on quality
choices.outcome: You didn't try to be fancy. Good cheese, honest service. Some regulars brought friends. "My fromag√®re," they said, introducing you. It felt... real.

choices.text: Push hard - fake it till you make it
choices.hint: Pretend you know what you're doing
choices.outcome: You stayed late making gift baskets. Copied what the big shops did. Some sold, some didn't. You made money, but you felt like an imposter the whole time.

choices.text: Ask other shop owners for advice
choices.outcome: Marie from the bakery next door showed you how she handles December. "Next year," she said, "you'll know." She was right. You learned more from that conversation than from any business course.

christmas_market.title: Christmas Market Opportunity
christmas_market.description: The commune is organizing a Christmas market at Place Dumont. They're offering you a stand. It's three weekends of early mornings in the cold‚Äîbut you could sell Raclette portions, vin chaud pairings, and Gaufrinettes Tante Arlette.

choices.outcome: Three weekends, 6am starts, fingers frozen. But you sold 50kg of Raclette, 30 bottles of Montepulciano. New customers discovered you. "Where is your shop?"
You stayed warm in your shop. The Saturday orders piled up anyway. Probably the right call for your sanity.

building_offer.title: Madame Malfait Calls
building_offer.description: Your landlord, Madame Malfait, calls with news: "I'm selling the building. ‚Ç¨380,000. You have first right of refusal. I need an answer by January, and the sale closes in July." ‚Ç¨380,000. You'd need about ‚Ç¨80,000 cash for the down payment and fees. You have... not that.

choices.text: "I'll find a way. I want it."
choices.hint: Start saving aggressively - you have 8 months
choices.outcome: You said yes. ‚Ç¨80,000 by July. Every euro counts now. No fancy equipment. No expensive signs. Every profit goes to the building fund.
"I can give you until January to decide," she said. "But the price is firm." The clock is ticking.

choices.text: "I can't afford it. Thank you anyway."
choices.outcome: You let it go. The building sold to an investor. Your new landlord is... different. Rent increases are coming.

meet_lucas.title: The Neighbor Kid
meet_lucas.description: Lucas works at a shop next door. Young, chaotic energy, passionate about food. He keeps stopping by, asking about the cheese. "I'd love to work with products like this," he says. He has other gigs on the side, but seems genuinely interested.

choices.outcome: Lucas started. He's late sometimes. He talks too much. But customers LOVE him. And he actually cares about cheese.
You posted job listings. The candidates were... fine. Professional. None of them had Lucas's spark.

choices.text: Not yet, keep doing it yourself
choices.outcome: You kept working alone. Every hour in the shop was an hour away from everything else.

adopt_dog.title: The Dog Question
adopt_dog.description: Your partner has been hinting for months. A friend's Australian Shepherd just had puppies‚Äîgorgeous, smart, absolutely full of energy. "It would be good for us," they say. "You need something that isn't the shop." An Aussie is a lot of dog. Walks, training, stimulation. But those eyes...

choices.hint: Vet bills, food, gear, time away from shop
choices.outcome: You named him Poncho. He's a whirlwind of fur and love. Vet visits, premium food, endless toys. And the walks take time you could be at the shop. But those eyes when he looks at you. Worth every euro.
You said no. "Maybe next year." Your partner's face fell. The shop consumed another piece of your life.

raclette_season.title: Raclette Season!
raclette_season.description: Winter is here and everyone wants raclette. You could stock up big on raclette cheese and rent machines. High investment but the margins are incredible.

choices.outcome: You bought 200kg of raclette cheese and 5 machines to rent. Sold out by January. The profit was beautiful.
You kept normal stock levels. Sold what you had, no stress.

birthday_forgot.title: The Birthday You Forgot
birthday_forgot.description:
It's 22h. You're finally home, exhausted. Your phone buzzes - a photo in the family group chat. Cake, candles, your mother smiling. The caption: "Missed you today!"

Your mother's birthday. You forgot completely. Not even a call.

choices.outcome: She opened the door surprised. "I knew you were busy." Her voice was gentle, which made it worse. You apologized. She said it was fine. It wasn't fine.

choices.text: Send flowers tomorrow with a long apology
choices.outcome: The flowers arrived the next day. Beautiful. Expensive. Your mother called to thank you. The conversation was short. Polite. You could hear the distance.

christmas_day.title: Christmas Day
christmas_day.description: December 25th. The shop is closed today and tomorrow - finally. Your family expects you at 13h for Christmas lunch. But the shop is chaos. Stock everywhere, orders half-prepared, the 27th reopening looms. You could "just pop in for a few hours" this morning to get ahead...

choices.outcome: You left the chaos behind. Ate too much. Laughed with cousins. Fell asleep on the couch. The mess waited for you on the 26th. You dealt with it. Somehow you always do.

choices.text: "Just a few hours" at the shop first
choices.outcome: A few hours became six. You arrived at 19h, dessert already finished. "You're here!" your mother said, not quite hiding her disappointment. The shop was ready for the 27th. The price was on your family's faces.
You spent Christmas alone in the shop, Radio Nostalgie playing carols. Got everything perfect for the 27th. Called your mother at 20h. "Maybe next year," she said.

family_dinner.title: Sunday Dinner
family_dinner.description: Your family is gathering this Sunday. You haven't been to a family dinner in months. The shop needs you. They need you too.

choices.outcome: The roast was delicious. Your niece has grown. For a few hours, you weren't a shopkeeper‚Äîjust family.
Another empty chair at the table. Your mother asked about you. Your partner made excuses. But the shop ran smoothly.

the_invitation.title: The Invitation
the_invitation.description: Your friend Marc is getting married. Saturday, of course. You're invited - actually, you're expected. You've known him since university. The ceremony is at 14h, reception until late. Saturday is your best day. ‚Ç¨2,000+ in sales, and customers who don't find you open will try somewhere else.

choices.hint: Marc would do the same for me
choices.outcome: You danced at Marc's wedding. The shop was dark. Some customers found other shops that day. Some of them never came back. But Marc hugged you and said "I'm glad you came." That mattered.

choices.hint: They can handle one Saturday... right?
choices.outcome: You got the call at 16h. Problem with a delivery. Angry customer. You left the reception early, still in your suit, and spent the evening fixing things. You made it back for the last dance. Barely.
You sent a gift and a card. Marc said he understood. You worked a normal Saturday. The cheese sold well. You tried not to think about it.

hospital_call.title: The Hospital Call
hospital_call.description: Your mother calls. Your father had a fall - he's in the hospital in Li√®ge. Not life-threatening, but he's scared and asking for you. It's December 18th. Your busiest week. The shop is packed with people buying Christmas cheese.

choices.outcome: You drove to Li√®ge that night. The shop stayed closed three days. Customers went elsewhere. Your father held your hand and said "You came." December was a disaster financially. But you were there.
You worked 6h-18h, then drove two hours to Li√®ge, sat with him until midnight, drove back, slept four hours, repeated. For a week. Your body remembers this.

choices.hint: The shop can't survive without me right now
choices.outcome: You called twice a day. Sent flowers. Your mother's voice was polite but distant. Your father recovered. They said they understand.

old_friend.title: The Old Friend
old_friend.description: Thomas is passing through Brussels. You haven't seen him in three years - he moved to Berlin, life happened. He's free tonight only. "Drinks? Dinner? Like old times?" It's Friday. Cheese delivery tomorrow at 6h. You know yourself - if you go out tonight, tomorrow will hurt.

choices.outcome: You stayed out until 2h. Talked about everything. Laughed until your stomach hurt. The alarm at 5h30 was brutal. You moved through Saturday like a zombie. Worth it? You think so.

choices.text: Invite him to the shop instead
choices.hint: He can see what I've built
choices.outcome: Thomas came by at 18h. You gave him the tour, the story, the best cheese. He was impressed. "You really built something." It wasn't the same as a real night out, but it was something.

choices.hint: I can't, I have work tomorrow
choices.outcome: You texted "Next time for sure." There wasn't a next time. Thomas didn't come back through Brussels. You wonder sometimes what you would have talked about.

second_shop_offer.title: The Call from Rue au Bois
second_shop_offer.description:
Your phone rings. It's Marie, a fellow fromag√®re. "Julien, I'm retiring. My shop on Rue au Bois... I thought of you first. ‚Ç¨60,000 for everything - the clientele, the suppliers, the name. Interested?"

A second location. Double the revenue. Double the complexity. You never bought the building here... but you could build an empire instead.

choices.text: Let's do it - expand the empire
choices.outcome: You signed the papers. Chez Julien is now two shops. Your accountant looked at you like you were crazy. Maybe you are. But maybe... this is just the beginning.

choices.hint: You have the money. You choose peace.
choices.outcome: "I'm flattered, Marie. But I've built something here. One shop, done well. That's enough for me." She smiled. "I understand. You've found your contentment."

charcuterie_question.title: The Charcuterie Question
charcuterie_question.description: A customer lingers at the cheese counter. "Do you have any charcuterie? A nice saucisson to go with this Comt√©?" You don't. But Coprosain has excellent Belgian products, and From'Un carries Italian imports...

choices.hint: Local products, good story, modest investment
choices.outcome: You called Coprosain. Fuetec, Saucisson d'Ard√®che, Coppa... The Belgian angle resonates with customers. "Local AND delicious."
Prosciutto di Parma, Bresaola, 'Nduja... The Italian selection draws a new crowd. Higher prices, higher margins.
"We're a cheese shop," you explain. The customer nods, respects the focus. Simplicity has its own value.

wine_dilemma.title: The Wine Dilemma
wine_dilemma.description: "What wine goes with this cheese?" You get asked this daily. The wine shop on Rue au Bois is good, but... what if you had a small selection here? Cheese and wine together sell better than apart.

choices.outcome: A small but perfect selection. C√¥tes du Rh√¥ne, Bourgogne, a few surprises. Cheese sales actually increase - pairings work.

choices.hint: Big investment, new customer segment, more complexity
choices.outcome: You did a wine course, built relationships with importers. The wine section rivals specialty shops. New customers discover you through wine.
You struck a deal with Marie at the wine shop. You recommend each other. No inventory risk, but you share the customer.

cheap_fridge.title: The Barely-Working Fridge
cheap_fridge.description: You found a used cheese display counter for ‚Ç¨800. It's ugly. The compressor sounds like a dying cat. But it works. A proper state-of-the-art counter would be ‚Ç¨50,000.

choices.hint: Save cash for the building fund
choices.outcome: The fridge hums loudly. Customers joke about it. But cheese stays cold and you have ‚Ç¨49,200 more for other things. Smart.
The new counter is magnificent. Temperature-controlled zones, LED lighting, the works. ‚Ç¨800/month for 5 years. Worth it? Time will tell.

fine_food_choice.title: A New Direction
fine_food_choice.description:
Looking at the shop, you realize it's becoming something different. The bulk bins are emptier, the cheese counter is busier. A customer says, "This feels more like a fine food shop now."

Maybe it's time to embrace that identity fully?

choices.text: Embrace fine food - this is who we are now
choices.outcome: You've made the decision. This is a fine food shop now. The identity feels clear, authentic. Customers sense it too.
You decide to keep the mix for now. Maybe clarity will come later.

sunday_burnout.title: The Crash
sunday_burnout.description: It's been a year. You've worked every single day. Sunday was supposed to be "just a few extra hours." Your body has different plans. You wake up and literally cannot get out of bed. Not metaphorically. Physically cannot.

choices.outcome: You closed the shop. "FERM√â POUR RAISONS PERSONNELLES." A week in bed. Your body slowly forgave you. The cheese didn't - ‚Ç¨5,000 in spoilage and lost sales.
You dragged yourself to the shop. Made mistakes. Snapped at customers. Your partner watched in horror.

stop_sunday.title: The Sunday Decision
stop_sunday.description: After the crash, you're rethinking everything. Sunday was only your 4th best day anyway. The extra revenue wasn't worth the toll. Maybe it's time to reclaim your rest.

choices.outcome: The sign now says "Ferm√© le Dimanche." Regular Sunday customers found other shops. Your body celebrated; your bank account mourned.
You found someone to cover Sundays. It's not the same, but at least you're not there.

relationship_tension.title: The Talk
relationship_tension.description: "We need to talk about the shop." Your partner sits you down. They're worried. You're always working. Always stressed. Always tired. "I feel like I'm losing you to cheese."

choices.outcome: You made promises. Specific ones. Date nights mean leaving early. Sunday mornings off mean lost sales. You kept them. It hurt the bottom line, but it helped. A little.

choices.text: "This is temporary - I need support right now"
choices.outcome: They heard you. But you saw disappointment. The shop is winning. That's not nothing.

choices.text: Hire more help so you can be present
choices.outcome: You found someone for Saturday afternoons. Date nights returned. The extra ‚Ç¨2,500/month in wages hurts, but the relationship is worth it.

sleep_problems.title: The 3am Wake-ups
sleep_problems.description: For the past two weeks, you've been waking up at 3am. Mind racing. Did you order enough Comt√©? Is the rent paid? What if the cheese counter fails? Sleep won't come back.

choices.outcome: The insomnia continued. You functioned, barely. Made more mistakes than usual.
The doctor listened. Suggested some changes. Gave you something to help. Slowly, sleep returned.
The walks became ritual. Brussels at dusk. Poncho happy. Mind quieter. Sleep came easier.

summer_flood.title: The Flood

choices.hint: This is why you paid for coverage
choices.outcome: The insurance adjuster came within 48 hours. They covered most of it: ‚Ç¨4,000 for damaged goods, ‚Ç¨1,500 for cleanup, plus ‚Ç¨1,000 for "business interruption." The deductible stung, but better than paying ‚Ç¨18,000 out of pocket.

choices.text: Clean up and absorb the loss
choices.outcome: A week of cleanup. ‚Ç¨18,000 in damaged inventory and equipment. The basement fridge died. Stock ruined. No insurance payout. You watch months of savings drain away. This is the price of gambling on cheap insurance.

choices.hint: They can only cover part of this disaster
choices.outcome: Your parents helped with cleanup. Your brother scraped together ‚Ç¨5,000. But the damage is ‚Ç¨18,000. You still lost ‚Ç¨13,000. Family saved you from bankruptcy, but the resentment lingers. You owe them everything now.

summer_flood.description: August. Freak summer storm. You arrive at the shop to find water pouring in through the basement. The cheese fridge is fine‚Äîit's elevated‚Äîbut the basement storage is devastated. Boxes of slow-moving bulk products, seasonal decorations, old equipment. All ruined.

corporate_opportunity.title: The Corporate Inquiry
corporate_opportunity.description: An email from a law firm downtown: "We're looking for a caterer for our weekly partner meetings. Cheese platters, quality important, reliability essential. Can you deliver every Thursday?"

choices.outcome: Every Thursday, 6am, you prep their platters. It's work. But ‚Ç¨2,000/month, guaranteed, forever. That's stability.

choices.hint: Higher price, less frequent, or they find someone else
choices.outcome: You pushed back. They agreed to bi-weekly at higher margins. Less reliable, but less draining.
"We're focused on our retail customers," you explain. They understand. You remain master of your schedule.

gradual_pivot.title: The Gradual Transformation
gradual_pivot.description: You've been slowly replacing bulk bins with cheese, charcuterie, local products. The transformation is visible. Old customers grumble. New ones appear. "Is this still an organic shop?" someone asks.

choices.hint: One product category at a time, keep cash flow stable
choices.outcome: Another bulk section becomes a cheese display. The transformation continues, gradual and sustainable.
Major renovation weekend. The shop looks different. Some regulars are shocked. New customers are delighted.

corporate_client.title: A Corporate Inquiry
corporate_client.description: An architecture firm down the street wants monthly plateaux for their Friday ap√©ros. "Three cheeses, some charcuterie, maybe those Cookies from G√¢teau sur la Cerise?" They want to order every month. Regular orders, good margins‚Äîbut you'll need to prep 8 plateaux every Thursday evening.

choices.outcome: Every Thursday you prep 8 plateaux: Comt√© 8 mois, Manchego DOP, Coppa di Parma, Saucisson d'Ard√®che. Predictable income. Your accountant is finally happy.
You politely declined. Thursday is already Interbio delivery day. One more task would break you.

wine_pairing.title: Wine & Cheese Evenings
wine_pairing.description: A local sommelier proposes hosting wine and cheese tasting evenings in your shop. Thursday nights, once a month. "We pair the Montepulciano-Merlot with aged Comt√©, the Tenuta Ulisse with Manchego..." Split the profits.

choices.outcome: The first evening was packed. Word spread. People who never bought cheese are now regulars.
You passed. Maybe another time when things are calmer.

first_raclette_season.title: The Raclette Question
first_raclette_season.description: October. Your second autumn in the shop. The temperature drops. Customers start asking: "Do you have raclette?" You have a few basic wheels, but you could do more. Much more. Raclette season is coming‚Äîthe question is whether you want to ride it.

choices.outcome: You ordered 8 different raclettes: classic, fum√©e, poivre, herbes de Provence... The display looks impressive. Customers are intrigued. "You have HOW many raclettes?"
You got three solid raclettes: a Swiss, a French, and a smoked. Enough to satisfy demand without the risk.
You passed on the raclette craze. Let the supermarkets fight over it.

swiss_invitation.title: The Swiss Invitation
swiss_invitation.description:
An email from Valais, Switzerland. A raclette producer you've been ordering from. "Julien, why don't you come visit? See the cows, the alpine pastures, understand why our raclette is different. One week. We'll show you everything."

It would cost ‚Ç¨4,000 and the shop would close for a week. But the connections, the knowledge, the story...

choices.hint: A week in the Alps with cheese makers...
choices.outcome: The Alps were breathtaking. You met farmers whose families have made raclette for generations. Tasted varieties you'd never heard of: truffle-infused, lavender & muscat, smoked over beechwood, even one with chili. They gave you exclusive supplier access. You came back transformed.

choices.hint: ‚Ç¨4,000 and a week closed is too much
choices.outcome: You wrote back with regrets. "Maybe next year." The invitation didn't come again.

raclette_kingdom.title: The Raclette Kingdom
raclette_kingdom.description:
You've built something special. Customers come from across Brussels for your raclette selection. But you could go further: dedicate a whole corner to raclette, rent machines year-round, become THE destination. Twenty varieties. A raclette bar. The full experience.

It's a big commitment. But so was everything else that got you here.

choices.outcome: You renovated the corner. Twenty raclette varieties displayed like jewels. Five machines available for rent. A sign: "La Maison de la Raclette." Food bloggers started posting. You became a destination.

choices.hint: Raclette is great, but so are other cheeses
choices.outcome: You kept your excellent raclette selection without going all-in. A balanced shop, not a raclette shrine. That's okay too.

parmigiano_invitation.title: The King of Cheeses Calls
parmigiano_invitation.description:
An email arrives from Emilia-Romagna, Italy. A consortium of Parmigiano Reggiano producers has heard of your shop. "We invite you to our mountains. Three days, all inclusive‚Äîstay at the farmstead, see the cows, watch the wheels being made, taste 24-month, 36-month, 72-month aged. The full experience."

‚Ç¨6,000 for everything. It's the trip of a lifetime for a fromager. The crowning achievement of building relationships with producers.

choices.hint: This is the dream. The absolute peak.
choices.outcome: The Apennine mountains. Dawn milking. Copper cauldrons bigger than cars. You watched masters at work‚Äîthe same movements their grandfathers made. The 72-month Parmigiano brought tears to your eyes. You came back changed. Not just a shopkeeper anymore. A true fromager.
You wrote back declining. "Business constraints." They understood. You wondered, for years after, what those mountains looked like at dawn.

birthday_party.title: Your Birthday Approaches
birthday_party.description: Your birthday is coming up. Your partner has been hinting. "We should do something at the shop. Invite everyone‚Äîcustomers, suppliers, friends. Celebrate what you've built." It would be chaos. Wonderful chaos. Or you could keep it small‚Äîdinner with close ones, no stress.

choices.text: Throw the big party at the shop
choices.hint: A proper party costs real money
choices.outcome: The shop was packed. Regulars, producers, old friends, new friends. Someone brought a cake shaped like a wheel of Comt√©. Your supplier from Auvergne drove up with a special cheese just for you. Open bar, catering, decorations - ‚Ç¨4,500 later, it was exhausting. It was perfect.

choices.text: Keep it small‚Äîdinner with loved ones
choices.outcome: A quiet dinner at a nice restaurant. Good wine. Stories told. No one needed to see the shop. The people who mattered already knew.

regular_appreciation.title: The Regulars' Gift
regular_appreciation.description: A group of your most loyal customers shows up with a wrapped package. "Three years you've been feeding us. We wanted to say thank you." Inside: a beautiful wooden cheese board, hand-carved, with "Chez Julien" engraved on the back.

choices.text: Display it proudly in the shop
choices.hint: Let everyone see what community means
choices.outcome: You hung it behind the counter. Customers notice. "What's that?" "A gift from regulars." It became part of the story.

choices.text: Keep it at home, use it for family dinners
choices.outcome: It sits on your dining table now. Every cheese night, you think of them.

competitor_closes.title: The Competition Closes
competitor_closes.description: You hear the news: the cheese shop on Avenue Louise is closing. They couldn't make it work‚Äîtoo high rent, not enough differentiation. Their customers need somewhere to go. Some will find you.

choices.outcome: You made some calls. Picked up two excellent suppliers they were working with. Their loss, your gain.

choices.text: Just let the customers find you naturally
choices.outcome: Over the next months, familiar faces started appearing. "We used to go to..." "I know. Welcome."

apprentice_request.title: The Apprentice
apprentice_request.description: A culinary school student emails you. They want to do a stage‚Äîan apprenticeship‚Äîat your shop. "I want to learn from someone who really knows cheese." It would be work to teach them. But it's also... flattering.

choices.text: Take them on for a month
choices.outcome: They were eager, clumsy, full of questions. By the end, they could run the counter alone. They wrote about you in their thesis.
You wrote back with regrets. "Maybe next year when things are calmer." Things never got calmer.

food_blogger_visit.title: The Food Blogger
food_blogger_visit.description: Someone's been taking a lot of photos in the shop. You recognize her from Instagram‚Äîshe has 50,000 followers and writes about Brussels food scene. She asks if she can interview you.

choices.text: Give her the full tour and interview
choices.outcome: She posted a 10-photo carousel with glowing captions. Your Instagram followers tripled. New faces appeared for weeks.
She was disappointed but understood. Took a few photos anyway. Tagged you in a story. Small wave of new customers.

reflection_moment.title: A Moment to Reflect
reflection_moment.description: It's a quiet Tuesday afternoon. The shop is empty for once. You look around‚Äîat the cheese counter you built, the photos on the wall, the rhythm you've created. How far you've come from that first terrifying month.

choices.outcome: You sat on your stool, ate a piece of Comt√©, and smiled. Not everything was perfect. But you built something real.
You pulled out a notebook. Expansion? Teaching? Writing a book? The future was wide open.

newspaper_feature.title: Local Newspaper Calls
newspaper_feature.description: A journalist from the local paper wants to write a feature about your shop. "The neighborhood cheese revolution" they're calling it. Free publicity.

choices.outcome: The article came out. Your phone didn't stop ringing. New customers came from three communes over.

choices.text: Prefer to stay under the radar
choices.outcome: You politely declined. Privacy has its value.

expand_hours.title: Extended Hours?
expand_hours.description: Customers keep asking if you could stay open later. "I get off work at 6, you close at 6!" Opening until 7:30pm could capture the after-work crowd.

choices.outcome: The after-work crowd found you. Sales went up, especially on weekdays.
You kept your evenings. Some things are worth more than money.

talk_to_customers.title: The Listening Tour
talk_to_customers.description: You've noticed something: the more you chat with customers, the more you understand what they want. Madame Hermans mentioned a specific Italian cheese. Mr. Peeters asked about wine pairings. They're telling you what to sell.

choices.outcome: You spent extra time with each customer. Learned names, preferences, stories. They started bringing friends.
Quick and professional. But you missed something‚Äîthe connection that makes a neighborhood shop special.

christmas_rush.title: The Christmas Chaos
christmas_rush.description: December hits like a truck. Raclette, Comt√©, Beaufort d'√©t√©‚Äîeveryone wants cheese platters. Coppa di Parma, Saucisson d'Ard√®che noisette, Prosciutto Riserva for the charcuterie boards. The Montepulciano-Merlot flies off the shelf. Interbio's Thursday delivery isn't enough‚Äîyou place emergency orders. The queue stretches out the door. You haven't eaten lunch in three days.

choices.outcome: You survived December. Barely. Sold 40 wheels of Raclette, 200 bottles of wine, countless plateaux. Revenue was incredible. Your body... less so.

choices.text: Set boundaries - close on time, limit orders
choices.outcome: You stopped taking platter orders after December 20th. Some customers grumbled. But you made it through human, not hospitalized.

summer_slowdown.title: Summer Drought
summer_slowdown.description: August. Brussels empties. Your regulars are at the coast. The Melon Charentais bio sells well, but cheese sales drop 40%. Some Ch√®vre Frais went past its prime. The St Marcellin didn't make it. The waste hurt, but you held your value.

choices.text: Take a week off - embrace it
choices.hint: A real vacation costs real money
choices.outcome: You closed for a week. First real break in months. The Belgian coast was healing. Let the cheese age in peace. But that week cost you - lost sales, spoiled stock, the vacation itself.

heat_wave.title: The Heat Wave

choices.outcome: You bought bags of ice, rented extra coolers. The cheese survived. You were drenched in sweat by closing time.

choices.outcome: Mozzarella di Bufala, fresh ch√®vre, light salads. You adapted. Some aged cheese suffered, but you moved what mattered.

snow_day.title: Brussels Under Snow
snow_day.description: You wake up to 20cm of snow. Brussels is paralyzed. The tram isn't running. Cars are stuck. Your delivery from Lalero? "Impossible today." But some brave souls might still walk to shops...

choices.hint: The few who make it will remember
choices.outcome: You trudged through the snow. Only 12 customers all day. But they were SO grateful. "You're the only shop open!" Hot chocolate for everyone.

choices.text: Stay closed - it's not worth it
choices.hint: A day off costs more than you think
choices.outcome: You stayed home. Built a snowman. Watched the city sleep. The cheese aged unpurchased. Fixed costs don't stop for snow.

back_to_school.title: September Rush

Suddenly they need everything: Filet de Poulet Coprosain for quick dinners, Bolognaise Fra√Æche for the kids, cheese for the raclette they're already craving. Your September stats show ‚Ç¨35,000 turnover, 1,649 clients. The rhythm is brutal after summer's calm.

choices.outcome: September was intense but profitable. Your rhythm is back.
You didn't catch every sale, but you didn't burn out either.

supplier_price_hike.title: The Lalero Letter

The Tomme Larzac, the Comt√© 8 mois, the Boerentrots Tentation‚Äîall going up. Your margins on cheese (your best category at 20% of sales) just got squeezed.

choices.outcome: You spent an evening updating labels. The Tomme went from ‚Ç¨29 to ‚Ç¨33/kg. Some regulars noticed. "C'est la vie," said one. Another just walked out.

choices.hint: Keep customers happy, build loyalty long-term
choices.outcome: You ate the difference. Margins hurt now. But Madame Dubois noticed you didn't raise prices. "You're not like the others," she said. She'll remember.

choices.hint: Risky, but could pay off if you have leverage
choices.outcome: You called Lalero and pushed back. They blinked. "For you, Julien, 8% instead of 15%." Relationships matter.

delivery_disaster.title: The Interbio No-Show

choices.hint: Buy retail, sell retail - margins will hurt
choices.outcome: You spent the morning at the market. Paid retail prices for what you'll sell at barely more. But the shelves weren't empty.

choices.text: Make do with what you have
choices.hint: Focus on cheese and charcuterie today
choices.outcome: The produce section looked sad. "Pas de l√©gumes?" Some customers left with only half their list. The cheese carried the day.

health_inspection.title: AFSCA Visit
health_inspection.description: Two inspectors from AFSCA walk in unannounced. Clipboards. Thermometers. Questions. Your heart rate doubles. Everything is fine... right?

choices.outcome: Two hours of scrutiny. A few minor notes. But you passed. The relief was physical. You actually feel better now that it's done.

choices.hint: Fake it till you make it
choices.outcome: You smiled while dying inside. They noticed one fridge was 1¬∞C too warm. Warning issued. Not the end of the world.

competitor_opens.title: New Competition
competitor_opens.description: A new "artisan fromagerie" opens three streets away. Slick branding. Instagram presence. Younger owner. You see some of your regulars walking past with their bags.

choices.text: Double down on what makes you different
choices.hint: Your story, your selection, your service
choices.outcome: You focused on relationships. The regulars who matter stayed. Some even came back after trying them.
You walked in pretending to be a customer. Nice place. But you noticed things they were missing. Ideas formed.

choices.text: Ignore them and focus on your work
choices.outcome: You tried not to think about it. But every slow day, you wondered if they were busy.

fridge_breakdown.title: The Fridge Dies
fridge_breakdown.description: The main display fridge starts making a horrible noise. Then stops. The temperature is rising. You have ‚Ç¨3,000 worth of cheese in there.

choices.text: Emergency repair - pay whatever it takes
choices.outcome: The technician came within hours. ‚Ç¨1,200 for a Sunday callout. The cheese was saved. Barely.

choices.text: Move everything to the backup fridge
choices.outcome: You spent hours shuffling cheese. The backup fridge is smaller. Some things had to be sold at a loss.

producer_visit_lalero.title: The Lalero Invitation
producer_visit_lalero.description: Email from Lalero: "Cher Julien, we're inviting our best clients to visit our caves in Aveyron. Two days, all expenses paid except travel. You'd see how Tomme Larzac is made, meet the affineurs..."

choices.text: Go - close the shop for 2 days
choices.hint: Lost sales now, but relationships and knowledge forever
choices.outcome: The caves were magical. You understand the cheese differently now. Lalero treats you as family. Future orders will be prioritized, prices negotiated. You came back with ideas for 8 new cheeses to stock.
Henry came back transformed. "Julien, I understand now. The cheese has a story." His passion grew. Worth it.
"Maybe next year," you write. The opportunity passes. There's always next year... right?

cheese_course.title: The Cheese Certification
cheese_course.description: A prestigious 3-day cheese certification course in Lyon. ‚Ç¨1,200 plus travel. The certificate means nothing to customers, but the knowledge... affineurs, terroir, pairings, aging techniques.

choices.hint: ‚Ç¨1,500 + lost sales, but expertise is forever
choices.outcome: Three days of intensive learning. You came back different. The way you talk about cheese changed. Customers notice. They trust you more. You discovered 6 regional cheeses you'd never heard of‚Äîand now you stock them.

choices.hint: Free, but slower and less credible
choices.outcome: You watched videos at night. Learned some things. Not the same as being there, but something.

bulk_supplier_deal.title: The Lalero Bulk Offer
bulk_supplier_deal.description: Lalero offers 20% off if you commit to 3 months of orders upfront. That's ‚Ç¨4,000 now, but you'd save ‚Ç¨200/month for a year. The cash would be tied up, but the margins...

choices.outcome: You signed the commitment. Cash flow is tighter, but your margins just improved. Smart if you can survive the cash squeeze.

choices.hint: Same discount, pay monthly, but they'll want something
choices.outcome: Lalero agreed to monthly payments, but you committed to featuring their products prominently. A fair trade.
You kept your cash liquid. The discount would have been nice, but freedom has value too.

staff_training.title: Training Lucas
staff_training.description: Lucas is eager but clumsy with customers. You could spend a week really training him - role plays, product knowledge, the art of the sale. It would take your time, but imagine if he could actually sell...

choices.hint: Your time now, his competence forever
choices.outcome: A week of intense coaching. Lucas transformed. He recommends pairings now. Customers trust him. You can actually step away.

choices.text: Let him learn on the job
choices.outcome: Lucas improves, slowly. Some customers specifically wait for you. But he's getting there.

friend_needs_help.title: An Old Friend
friend_needs_help.description: Your best friend from before the shop days calls. They're going through a rough time. Divorce. They need someone to talk to. But talking takes time. Time you don't have.

choices.outcome: You listened. For hours. It felt good to be there for someone else. To remember you're more than the shop.
They called less. You felt guilty. But the shop demanded everything.

bad_review.title: One Star
bad_review.description: You open Google Maps. Someone left a 1-star review. "Overpriced cheese, rude owner." You remember them. They wanted a discount on everything. You politely declined. Now this.

choices.outcome: You wrote a calm, professional response. Other customers noticed. Some left supportive reviews. Taking action felt good.
It sat there. Unanswered. Every time someone mentioned reviews, you thought of it.
Awkward asks at the counter. But it worked. Twenty new 5-star reviews. The one-star was buried.

difficult_customer.title: The Complainer
difficult_customer.description: A customer brings back cheese, claiming it was "off." It wasn't - it's a washed-rind cheese, it's SUPPOSED to smell strong. But they're making a scene. Other customers are watching.

choices.outcome: You bit your tongue. Gave the refund. They left satisfied. You seethed.
You explained washed-rind cheeses. The origins. The process. They didn't care. Left angry.
You offered a gouda instead. They accepted. Crisis averted. Relationship saved.

regular_moves_away.title: Goodbye, Madame Dubois
regular_moves_away.description: Madame Dubois - your very first regular, the one who suggested cheese - comes in looking sad. She's moving. Closer to her grandchildren. "I'll miss this place."

choices.text: Give her a farewell cheese basket
choices.outcome: She cried. You almost did too. Some customers become family. She promised to visit when in town.
You told her what she meant to the shop. To you. She left with tears and promises to recommend you to everyone.

theft_incident.title: Sticky Fingers
theft_incident.description: You notice the expensive truffle cheese is missing from the display. Then you see it on the security camera: a customer slipping it into their bag while you helped someone else.

choices.text: Confront them next time they come
choices.hint: They will come back - they always do
choices.outcome: They returned two weeks later. You asked them to leave. They denied everything. Made a scene. Never came back.
You moved expensive items closer to the counter. Bought a small mirror. The ‚Ç¨85 loss stung, but peace was preserved.

choices.text: Post about it (anonymously) in local groups
choices.outcome: Other shopkeepers responded - they knew exactly who you meant. The neighborhood network was activated.

signature_cheese.title: Creating Your Signature
signature_cheese.description: You've been thinking... what if you created something unique? A cheese aged specifically for your shop, with your name on it. Lalero says they could work with an affineur to create "Tomme Chez Julien" - aged in their caves, exclusive to you.

choices.outcome: Six months later, the first wheel arrived. "Tomme Chez Julien" - your name on a cheese. Customers went crazy. Food magazines called. This is legacy.

choices.text: Not yet - focus on curation over creation
choices.hint: Being a great selector is enough
choices.outcome: You decided your skill is finding great cheeses, not making them. That's a valid path too.

shop_philosophy.title: What Do You Stand For?
shop_philosophy.description: A journalist asks you: "What's your philosophy?" You realize you've never articulated it. But you have one. What matters most to you about this shop?

choices.text: "Accessibility - great cheese for everyone, not just the elite"
choices.outcome: You wrote it on a small card by the register. "Good cheese is for everyone." Customers from all backgrounds felt welcome. Your prices stayed reasonable.

choices.text: "Education - I want people to discover, not just buy"
choices.outcome: You started offering free tastings every Saturday. Explaining terroir, aging, pairings. Customers became connoisseurs. They trusted you completely.

choices.hint: Remember names, support local, be part of the community
choices.outcome: You memorized every regular's name and preferences. Supported neighborhood events. Became the heart of the community, not just a shop.

mentor_opportunity.title: The Old Fromager
mentor_opportunity.description: Pierre, a retired fromager who ran a famous shop in Ixelles for 40 years, stops by. He's impressed. "You remind me of myself at your age. I could teach you things... if you want to learn." He offers to mentor you, one afternoon a week.

choices.hint: 40 years of wisdom, one afternoon at a time
choices.outcome: Every Tuesday, Pierre came. He taught you about affinage, about reading customers, about surviving the hard years. His stories were worth more than any course.

choices.text: Politely decline - forge your own path
choices.outcome: Pierre nodded, understanding. "Independent spirit. Good. You'll figure it out." He still stops by sometimes, just to chat.

neighborhood_collab.title: The Neighborhood Collective
neighborhood_collab.description: The bakery, the wine shop, and the butcher want to form a collective. Shared marketing, cross-promotions, maybe even a "neighborhood food tour" for tourists. You'd be the cheese stop.

choices.outcome: The "Woluwe Food Trail" launched. Tourists appeared with maps. Locals loved supporting "their" shops together. Rising tide lifts all boats.

choices.hint: You like doing things your way
choices.outcome: You stayed solo. The collective succeeded without you, but you kept your freedom. Sometimes you wonder what could have been.

cookbook_idea.title: The Recipe Collection
cookbook_idea.description: You've been collecting cheese recipes from customers for two years now. Madame Dubois's fondue. Mr. Peeters's tartiflette. That amazing fig and goat cheese tart. What if you compiled them into a little book?

choices.outcome: The little cookbook sold out in a month. People bought cheese just to try the recipes. Some customers cried seeing their recipe in print. "You remembered."

choices.text: Keep the recipes as a personal collection
choices.hint: Not everything needs to be a product
choices.outcome: The recipe cards stay in your drawer. Sometimes you share them one by one. That feels more personal anyway.

seasonal_ritual.title: Creating a Tradition
seasonal_ritual.description: You want to create something special - a yearly tradition that customers look forward to. Something that makes your shop unique in the neighborhood calendar.

choices.text: "Beaufort Season" - a spring celebration of alpine cheese
choices.hint: April event with mountain cheeses, raclette, fondue tastings
choices.outcome: The first Beaufort Season was magical. Alpine decorations, cow bells, cheese from specific chalets. Customers marked it in their calendars. A tradition was born.

choices.text: "Fromage et Vendanges" - autumn cheese and wine pairing
choices.outcome: Wine, cheese, harvest decorations. The sommelier from down the street partnered with you. It became THE autumn event in Woluwe.
The first Saturday of every month: Cheese School. 8 people, 5 cheeses, 2 hours of tasting and learning. They became your most loyal customers.

lucas_growth.title: Lucas Has an Idea
lucas_growth.description: Lucas approaches you nervously. "I've been thinking... what if we did TikToks? Show the cheeses, explain them, make it fun. I could do it." He shows you some videos he made at home. They're actually good.

choices.text: Let Lucas run the social media
choices.outcome: Lucas's first TikTok hit 50k views. "POV: Your cheese guy explains why this Comt√© is worth ‚Ç¨35/kg." Suddenly young people were discovering real cheese.

choices.text: Not yet - focus on the fundamentals
choices.outcome: Lucas was disappointed but understood. "Maybe when things slow down." You focused on what you know.

your_counter_story.title: The Stories Behind the Counter
your_counter_story.description: You realize every cheese in your counter has a story. The Tomme from the farm you visited. The Parmigiano from that magical trip. What if you made the stories visible? Little cards, photos, maps?

choices.outcome: Every cheese now has a story visible. "This Raclette comes from Bernard in Valais. I met his cows." Customers spend longer browsing. They connect.
You tell the stories when asked. It's more personal that way, even if fewer people hear them.

expansion_dream.title: The Second Location
expansion_dream.description: A space opened up in Uccle. Nice neighborhood, no cheese shop. Your accountant says you could afford the deposit. Your partner looks worried. Lucas is excited. Is this the dream... or overreach?

choices.outcome: The Uccle shop opened. Henry runs it. You split your time. It's chaos, but it's growth. You're building something bigger than yourself.

choices.text: Stay focused on one perfect shop
choices.outcome: You let the Uccle space go. "One shop, done perfectly." Your partner hugged you. Sometimes the bravest thing is saying no.

documentary_approach.title: The Documentary
documentary_approach.description: A filmmaker wants to make a short documentary about your shop. "The pivot from bulk to cheese - it's a story about following your instincts." She wants to follow you for a month.

choices.outcome: A month of cameras. Awkward at first, then you forgot they were there. The documentary premiered at a local film festival. Standing ovation. Your mom cried.

choices.hint: Some things are just for you
choices.outcome: You politely declined. The story stays yours, untold to strangers. That's okay too.

charity_choice.title: Giving Back
charity_choice.description: The local food bank asks if you'd donate cheese that's near its sell-by date. Also, a school wants you to do a free cheese education session. You can't do everything, but you want to do something.

choices.outcome: Every week, cheese that would've been waste went to families in need. It felt right. The food bank put your logo on their newsletter.
You went to three schools. Brought cheese samples. The kids were fascinated. Some dragged their parents to your shop later. "The cheese man!"
You stretched yourself, but it was worth it. The community saw who you really are. Some things matter more than profit.

naming_ceremony.title: The Naming Ceremony
naming_ceremony.description: It's official: customers have started calling your shop by a nickname. Some say "Julien's", some say "The Cheese Corner", some stick with "Chez Julien". Time to make it official?

choices.text: Embrace "Chez Julien" with a new sign
choices.outcome: The new sign went up. Hand-painted, beautiful. "Chez Julien - Fromagerie". Customers took photos. You felt... official.
No fancy sign. Just good cheese. Word of mouth was enough.

special_order.title: The Impossible Request
special_order.description: A customer asks: "Can you get √âpoisses aged by Berthaut himself? The one from before he retired?" It's nearly impossible. But you know someone who might know someone...

choices.outcome: Three weeks of calls, favors, connections. You found it. The customer wept when he saw it. "You actually did it." Your reputation for getting the impossible spread.
You explained the reality. They understood. Sometimes the answer is no, and that's okay.

lucas_brings_henry.title: Lucas Has a Friend
lucas_brings_henry.description: Lucas has been great. Unreliable sometimes, but customers adore him. One day he mentions his best friend Henry: "He's looking for work. Most reliable person I know. Complete opposite of me, actually."

choices.outcome: Henry started. He showed up every single day. On time. No drama. Lucas joked that Henry was making him look bad. Your life changed.
You passed on Henry. The December rush was coming. You'd manage somehow.

direct_hire_help.title: Time to Get Help
direct_hire_help.description: You've been running yourself ragged for over two years now. The shop needs another pair of hands. A former colleague from another shop reached out - she's looking for stable work.

choices.outcome: Sophie started Monday. She knew the rhythm of a shop. No training needed. For the first time in months, you took a lunch break.
Part-time help for the busy hours. Not a complete solution, but breathing room.

choices.hint: The money stays in the business
choices.outcome: You pushed through. Your body kept score.

student_trap.title: Student Workers
student_trap.description: A business advisor suggests hiring students. "Cheap labor! Flexible! Perfect for retail!" It sounds appealing‚Äîuntil you remember that students have exams in December. Your busiest month.

choices.hint: Cheap (‚Ç¨12/hour) but they vanish in December
choices.outcome: The student was great in October. In December? "Sorry, I have exams." You were alone for Christmas rush.

choices.text: Pass - find adults who can commit
choices.outcome: You held out for real employees. More expensive, but they'd actually show up when you needed them.

peak_performance.title: In The Zone
peak_performance.description: You wake up feeling... incredible. Rested. Clear-headed. Ready. It's been months since you felt this good. The shop hums along, customers smile, everything just clicks. You have energy to spare‚Äîtime to do something with it.

choices.text: Deep clean and reorganize the shop
choices.hint: Use this energy for the shop
choices.outcome: You spent the day reorganizing everything. The walk-in fridge is spotless. Products are perfectly displayed. Customers notice‚Äî"Did you renovate?" The satisfaction is immense.

choices.text: Visit a supplier you've been meaning to see
choices.hint: Build relationships while you have the energy
choices.outcome: You drove out to meet a producer face-to-face. Tasted cheeses you'd never find in catalogs. Came back with exclusive products and a real connection.

choices.text: Take a spontaneous day off with your partner
choices.hint: Closing early costs a full day of sales
choices.outcome: You closed early and surprised your partner. A long lunch, a walk by the canal, actual conversation. "I missed this," they said. So did you. The lost sales stung, but some things matter more.

choices.hint: Sometimes the reward is the energy itself
choices.outcome: You didn't do anything special‚Äîjust worked with a lightness you'd forgotten was possible. Customers felt it. You felt it. A good day.

dog_in_shop.title: Poncho Comes to Work
dog_in_shop.description: Poncho has become a shop mascot. He greets customers with boundless enthusiasm. Children come specifically to pet him. He needs walks between customers‚Äîyou can't sit still with an Aussie. But the joy he brings is undeniable.

choices.text: Lean into it - Poncho is part of the brand
choices.hint: Dog walks mean less time at the counter
choices.outcome: Poncho got his own Instagram. Customers who don't even buy anything stop by to see him. The walks between customers mean missed sales, but are actually... nice.
Poncho stayed home more. Customers asked where he was. Quieter, but something was missing.

poncho_cheese_emergency.title: Poncho's Cheese Incident
poncho_cheese_emergency.description: You turn your back for ONE minute. Poncho found the cheese samples meant for tomorrow's tasting‚Äîhalf a wheel of aged Comt√©, some Roquefort, a chunk of Gruy√®re. He ate it ALL. Now he's making concerning noises and won't stop drinking water. The vet says he needs surgery to remove a blockage.

choices.text: Rush him to the emergency vet
choices.outcome: The surgery went well. Poncho came home with the cone of shame, looking absolutely miserable but alive. Lucia nursed him back to health with infinite patience. You learned to lock the cheese samples away.

choices.text: Wait and see if he passes it naturally
choices.outcome: You waited too long. The emergency surgery cost ‚Ç¨4,000 instead. Poncho survived but it was close. The guilt lingers.

poncho_anniversary.title: Poncho's First Year
poncho_anniversary.description: One year ago, those eyes looked up at you from the shelter. Now Poncho owns the shop‚Äîhis chair by the door, his spot under the cheese counter, his adoring fans who come just to see him. He's not a puppy anymore. He's family.

choices.outcome: You gave him a whole slice of Beaufort. He deserved it. Lucia took photos of him sleeping in his favorite chair‚Äîall grown up now.

building_countdown.title: The Savings Push

choices.hint: No investments, no improvements, hoard cash
choices.outcome: You cut everything non-essential. The shop looks tired. But the bank account grows.

choices.hint: Steady progress without sacrificing the business
choices.outcome: You found the middle path. Essential investments only. Every other euro to savings.

building_countdown.description: The deadline for the ‚Ç¨80,000 is approaching. You look at your account. You know if you'll make it or not.

fancy_sign.title: The Shop Sign
fancy_sign.description: Everyone says you need a proper sign. "People don't even notice the shop!" A designer quotes ‚Ç¨2,000 for something beautiful. It would attract new customers. But ‚Ç¨2,000 could also be building fund money, or cheese stock.

choices.outcome: The sign went up. Beautiful. Eye-catching. New customers walked in. "I never noticed this shop before!"

choices.hint: Save money, word of mouth works
choices.outcome: You kept the simple sign. Regulars found you anyway. Growth was slower but organic.

producer_opportunity.title: Visit the Producers
producer_opportunity.description: A cheese supplier invites you to visit their farm in Wallonia. "See where it comes from. Meet the cows." It means closing the shop for a day. But customers love stories about provenance.

choices.hint: Close shop for a day, but gain knowledge and stories
choices.outcome: You drove to Wallonia. Met the cheesemaker. Heard the story. Customers love hearing about "your producer in Wallonia."
You said no. The supplier understood. You'll sell their cheese anyway, just without the story.
Lucas came back excited, full of stories. Not quite the same as going yourself, but the shop stayed open.

delegation_moment.title: Learning to Let Go
delegation_moment.description: You've been doing everything yourself. Opening, closing, ordering, pricing, cleaning. Lucas and Henry are capable, but you can't stop micromanaging. "You don't trust us," Lucas jokes. He's not entirely joking.

choices.hint: Training takes time, mistakes cost money
choices.outcome: You trained Lucas on ordering. Gave Henry keys. Their early mistakes cost you ‚Ç¨2,000 in misorders and waste. But they're learning.

choices.hint: Only you can do it right
choices.outcome: You stayed in control. Every decision went through you. Lucas and Henry stayed, but stopped offering ideas.

take_holiday.title: A Week Off?
take_holiday.description: You haven't taken a real holiday since you started. Your partner is begging. "Just one week. The shop won't collapse." It might. Or it might be fine.

choices.hint: A week off costs ‚Ç¨6,000 in lost sales and spoilage
choices.outcome: You went to the coast. Checked your phone obsessively at first. By day 3, you relaxed. The shop survived. Your savings... less so.
Three days away. Not enough, but something. Your partner was grateful for the crumbs. You lost ‚Ç¨2,500 in sales.
You stayed. Your partner went without you. The shop was fine. The relationship... less so.

december_rush.title: The December Rush
december_rush.description: December. The month that makes or breaks the year. Cheese platters, gift baskets, holiday orders. The shop is packed from morning to night. Everything you built leads to this.

choices.hint: Maximum stock, extended hours, capture everything
choices.outcome: You worked until midnight. Sold more than any other month. Collapsed on January 1st.
A strong December. Not record-breaking, but you entered January intact.

systems_project.title: Time to Systematize
systems_project.description: You've been thinking about efficiency. There are tools and systems that could help: email automation for suppliers, inventory software, even a cleaning service. Each takes time to set up, but could pay off.

choices.hint: Less time on admin, more on cheese
choices.outcome: A weekend setting up templates and auto-responses. Now supplier orders go out automatically. Invoices reminders too. You freed up hours each week.

choices.hint: One less thing to worry about
choices.outcome: Maria comes every Tuesday at 6am. The shop sparkles when you arrive. That weight off your shoulders? Priceless.
You filed the idea away. Maybe later, when there's more margin.

visibility_push.title: Building Visibility
visibility_push.description: The shop is good, but does the neighborhood know? You could invest time in getting the word out. Social media, local partnerships, maybe just walking around with samples.

choices.outcome: A week of photographing cheese in golden hour light. Posting daily. Hashtags. It felt silly at first. Then people started showing up. "I saw you on Instagram!"
You spent a Saturday visiting cheese shops in Ghent and Antwerp. Took notes. Stole ideas. Came back inspired. One display change already drew compliments.
You stayed in your lane. The regulars are loyal. That counts for something.

personal_recharge.title: Taking Care of Yourself
personal_recharge.description: The shop demands everything. But this month, you're thinking about yourself for once. A proper dinner. Seeing friends. Actually sleeping.

choices.outcome: Dinner at Comme Chez Soi with your contact from Lalero. Three hours of wine, cheese talk, and laughter. Business relationships are personal relationships.

choices.hint: Been a while since you were really present
choices.outcome: You took the weekend. Actually took it. Cooked together. Talked about things other than cheese. Your partner looked at you differently. Remembered.
Another month of grinding. The shop improves. You... less so. But momentum is momentum.

pricing_strategy.title: The Pricing Question
pricing_strategy.description: You've been thinking about your margins. Some shops charge premium prices and own it. Others compete on value. Where do you want to position yourself?

choices.outcome: You raised prices 10-15%. Some regulars grumbled. But new customers came who expected to pay for quality. Your margin improved noticeably.
You kept prices reasonable. The neighborhood appreciated it. Word spread that you were the fair cheese shop.

choices.text: Mixed strategy - everyday and special occasion
choices.outcome: You created two tiers. Everyday cheeses stayed accessible. The special stuff got premium pricing. More work managing it, but it felt right.

supplier_relationship.title: Supplier Strategy
supplier_relationship.description: You're ordering regularly now. Do you consolidate with fewer suppliers for better terms, or keep diversifying for unique products?

choices.outcome: You focused on three main suppliers. They gave you better payment terms and priority on rare products. Simpler is sometimes better.
You added two new small producers. One had an incredible aged goat cheese nobody else carried. Customers noticed the difference.

choices.hint: If it's working, don't fix it
choices.outcome: You maintained what was working. Sometimes the right move is no move.

weekly_rhythm.title: Finding Your Rhythm
weekly_rhythm.description: The shop has a pattern now. But you're wondering if you could optimize the week better. Different focus for different days?

choices.hint: Give people reasons to come specific days
choices.outcome: Tasting Tuesday. Fresh delivery Thursday. It took a few months, but regulars started planning around your schedule.
Tuesday and Wednesday mornings became sacred. Ordering, accounting, planning. The afternoons felt calmer knowing the admin was done.
You kept things fluid. Maybe that spontaneity was part of the charm.

learning_investment.title: Investing in Knowledge
learning_investment.description: There's a cheese certification course. Three weekends, ‚Ç¨800. Or you could visit producers in France. Or just keep learning by doing.

choices.outcome: Three intense weekends. Affineur certification. You learned things about aging you'd never have figured out alone. The certificate hangs in the shop.

choices.hint: See where it all comes from
choices.outcome: A week in Auvergne and Savoie. You saw cellars. Tasted things that never leave the region. Came back with stories and three new suppliers.
Every wheel taught you something. No certificate needed for that.

shop_atmosphere.title: The Shop Experience
shop_atmosphere.description: The shop works, but could it feel better? Music, lighting, the smell when people walk in - these things matter more than you thought.

choices.hint: Better lighting, subtle music, fresh flowers
choices.outcome: New warm lights. A carefully curated playlist. Fresh flowers on the counter. People started lingering longer. Buying more.

choices.hint: Let the cheese be the star
choices.outcome: You reorganized everything. Cheeses grouped by region, then by milk type. Labels with stories. Customers said it felt like a museum they could eat.
The shop had character. Maybe that was enough.

catering_opportunity.title: Catering Request
catering_opportunity.description: A local business wants cheese platters for their monthly client meetings. It's recurring revenue but requires early morning prep every second Friday.

choices.outcome: Every two weeks, you're up at 5am building platters. But ‚Ç¨800 lands in your account monthly. Reliable money feels different.
They agree to pick up. Simpler. Less margin, but you keep your mornings.
Not everything is worth chasing. Your schedule is already tight.

private_tasting.title: Private Tasting Request
private_tasting.description: Someone wants to book the shop for a private cheese tasting - their partner's 40th birthday. Eight people, Saturday evening after close.

choices.outcome: You pulled out your best cheeses, paired with local beers, told the stories. They were captivated. ‚Ç¨600 plus they'll tell everyone.

choices.hint: Good experience without burning yourself out
choices.outcome: An intimate evening. Good cheese, good conversation. ‚Ç¨300 and a lovely thank-you note the next week.

choices.text: Suggest they visit during open hours
choices.outcome: They understood. Some things aren't worth disrupting your rhythm for.

bulk_order.title: Restaurant Bulk Order

choices.hint: Significant volume, they feature you by name
choices.outcome: "Cheeses from Chez Julien" appears on their menu. The volume helps cash flow. Some of their customers become yours.
When they need something special, they call. No commitment, but good relationship.
You're a shop, not a wholesaler. You stay focused.

bulk_order.description: A restaurant wants to feature your cheeses on their menu. Regular weekly orders, but tight margins.

market_stall.title: Weekend Market Opportunity
market_stall.description: A spot opened up at the Dumont market. Every Wednesday afternoon. It's good exposure but means another half-day of work.

choices.outcome: Wednesdays are exhausting now. But the market crowd loves you. Some follow you back to the shop. Revenue up noticeably.
Three months of market life. Learned a lot about what sells. Made some money. Then happily gave up the spot.
You let someone else have it. One thing at a time.

good_month.title: An Unexpectedly Good Month

choices.outcome: Straight into savings. You're learning that good months fund the bad ones.
New cheese knives. A better display fridge light. Small things that make the place feel more professional.
A nice dinner out. Told the story of the crazy busy Saturday. Your family saw you happy about work for once.

good_month.description: Something clicked this month. Maybe the weather. Maybe word of mouth. Whatever it was, the register kept ringing.

quiet_month.title: A Quiet Month
quiet_month.description: Nothing dramatic. The rhythm continues. Customers come, cheese sells, the sun rises and sets. Sometimes that's enough.

choices.outcome: A peaceful month. You left on time a few days. Remembered what relaxation felt like.

choices.hint: Work on the business, not in it
choices.outcome: You reorganized. Made lists. Thought about the future.
